metadata.title: Nonlocal strain gradient beam model for nonlinear secondary resonance analysis of functionally graded porous micro/nano-beams under periodic hard excitations

sections.text:
ARTICLE HISTORY Received 11 March 2019 Accepted 23 May 2019
KEYWORDS Porous material; nonlinear dynamics; Gaussian-random field scheme; size dependency; multiple timescales method

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In the last decade, additive manufacturing technique has become a popular technology which results in the production of porous materials, especially functionally graded porous materials (FGPMs). Also, in addition to fabrication of FGPMs, a great attention has been devoted to study their mechanical characteristics under various loading conditions.
Zhang and Wang (2017) used thermal-bonding lamination technique to fabricate FGPMs including the both closed cell and open cell porosities. Wang, Xie, and Fu (2018a) performed a finite element analysis for free and forced vibrations of FGPM Euler–Bernoulli and Timoshenko
CONTACT A. M. Fattahi afattahi@uj.ac.za Color versions of one or more of the figures in the article can be found online at www.tandfonline.com/lmbd. Communicated by Wei-Chau Xie. 2019 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC
beams. Li et al. (2018a) explored the linear buckling and vibration behaviors of FGPM nanocomposite plates using the isogeometric analysis. Wang, Xie, and Fu (2018a) predicted the free and forced vibrations of FGPM tubes under the continuously distributed loads moving in the axial direction with a constant velocity. Sahmani, Aghdam, and Akbarzadeh (2018a), Sahmani, Aghdam, and Rabczuk (2018b) developed nonlocal strain gradient plate model for the sizedependent nonlinear large-amplitude vibrations and instability of FGPM nanocomposite micro/ nano-plates. Chen, Kitipornchai, and Yang (2018) studied the dynamic response and energy absorption of closed-cell FGPM structures with different porosity dispersions. Wu et al. (2018a, 2018b) examined the non-deterministic linear elastic of FGPM Timoshenko bars including uncertain but bounded system parameters via finite element method. Sahmani, Aghdam, and Rabczuk (2018c) analyzed the nonlinear bending behavior of FGPM nanocomposite micro/nano-beams under combination of axial and distributed loads based on the nonlocal strain gradient theory of elasticity. Karami, Janghorban, and Li (2018) anticipated the size-dependent guided wave propagation in mounted FGPM first-order shear deformable nanoplates.
In recent years, several unconventional continuum theories of elasticity have been introduced to capture different size-dependencies in mechanical responses of micro/nano-structures (Şimşek and Reddy 2013; Lei et al. 2013; Fu and Zhang 2013; Jain, Datta, and Majumder 2014; Reddy, ElBorgi, and Romanoff 2014; Jung, Han, and Park 2014; Sahmani, Bahrami, and Ansari 2014; Shojaeian and Tadi Beni 2015; Zhang et al. 2015; Jung and Han 2015; Sahmani, Aghdam, and Bahrami 2015; Xu and Yang 2015; Kiani 2016; Akbarzadeh Khorshidi, Shariati, and Emam 2016; Sahmani, Aghdam, and Bahrami 2017; Ziaee 2017; Sahmani and Aghdam 2017a, 2017b, 2017c; Li 2017; Kamenar and Zelenika 2017; Hashemi and Asghari 2017; Sahmani and Fattahi 2017a, 2017b; Tao and Fu 2017; Sui, Chen, and Yao 2017; Fattahi and Sahmani 2017a, 2017b; Sohi and Nieva 2018; Attia and Abdel Rahman 2018; Pang, Li, and Zhang 2018; Sahmani, Aghdam, and Akbarzadeh 2018a; Sahmani, Aghdam, and Rabczuk 2018b; Sahmani, Aghdam, and Rabczuk 2018c; Sahmani, Aghdam, and Rabczuk 2018d; Sahmani, Fattahi, and Ahmed 2018e, Sahmani, Fattahi, and Ahmed 2018f; Pinto and Mordehai 2018; Soleimani and Tadi Beni 2018; Li, Tang, and Hu 2018b; Sahmani and Khandan 2018; Dastjerdi and Tadi Beni 2018; Ghorbanpour Arani, Pourjamshidian, and Arefi 2018; Fang et al. 2018; Arefi and Soltan Arani 2018; Sahmani and Aghdam 2018a, 2018b, 2018c; Thai et al. 2018; Tohidi, Hosseini-Hashemi, and Maghsoudpour 2018; Sahmani and Aghdam 2019; Tang, Li, and Hu 2019a, Tang et al., 2019b; Sarafraz, Sahmani, and Aghdam 2019; Xu and Fu 2019; Sahmani, Fattahi, and Ahmed 2019; Sahmani, Fotouhi, and Aghdam 2019; Ansari and Kumar 2019). Also, recently, an integral form of the nonlocal elasticity has been employed to analyze size-dependent mechanical characteristics of micro/nano-structures (Zhu and Li 2017a, 2017b; Mahmoudpour, Hosseini-Hashemi, and Faghidian 2018; Fakher, Rahmanian, and Hosseini-Hashemi 2019). In accordance with reviewing the historical background, it is common that size effect in type of the stress nonlocality demonstrates softening influence caused a reduction in the stiffness, while the strain gradient small scale effect plays a hardening role made an increment in the value of stiffness. It means that the previous proposed unconventional continuum theories have not the capability to cover the size dependencies in a perfect way. So, a new size-dependent elasticity theory namely nonlocal strain gradient theory was developed by Lim, Zhang, and Reddy (2015).
After that, several investigation have been carried out using the new proposed non-classical continuum theory of elasticity. For instance, Li and Hu (2015) employed the nonlocal strain gradient theory of elasticity to analyze the nonlinear buckling characteristics of Euler–Bernoulli nanobeams. Additionally, they predicted the nonlocal strain gradient frequency of wave motion on nanotubes conveying fluid (Li and Hu 2016). Yang, Yang, and Wang (2016) anticipated the critical nonlocal strain gradient voltages associated with the pull-in instability of functionally graded nano-actuators. Simsek (2016) constructed a nonlocal strain gradient beam model for nonlinear vibrations of functionally graded Euler–Bernoulli nanobeams. Farajpour et al. (2016)
examined buckling behavior of orthotropic nonlocal strain gradient plates using a new sizedependent plate model. Tang, Liu, and Zhao (2017) analyzed the nonlocal strain gradient wave propagation in a viscoelastic nanotube. With the aid of the strain gradient elasticity theory, Sahmani and Aghdam (2017a, 2017b; 2018d, 2018e) studied the linear and nonlinear vibrations of supramolecular lipid micro/nano-tubules within the both prebuckling and postbuckling domains. Li, Tang, and Hu (2018c) anticipated the size-dependent bending, buckling and free vibration characteristics of axially functionally graded nonlocal strain gradient beams. Radwan and Sobhy (2018) explored the influences of nonlocality and strain gradient size dependency on the dynamic deformation of orthotropic viscoelastic graphene sheets subjected to a time harmonic thermal loading condition. Sahmani and Aghdam (2017f, 2017g, 2017h) reported analytical expressions for the nonlocal strain gradient nonlinear buckling and postbuckling behavior of hydrostatic pressurized multilayer functionally graded nanoshells. Wang et al. (2018b) introduced a nonlocal strain gradient beam model for complex modal analysis for vibrational response of axially moving beams at nanoscale. Sahmani and Safaei (2019) developed a nonlocal strain gradient beam model for nonlinear free vibrations of bidirectional FG micro/nano-beams.
For a structure under hard periodic excitation, the resonance phenomenon may be occurred within the excitation frequency range other than the natural frequency of the system, namely as the secondary resonance. For instance, a periodic hard excited beam-type structure with Duffing-type equation of motion, the associated secondary resonance can be occurred with subharmonic and superharmonic range of the excitation frequency. In the present work, for the first time, the size-dependent nonlinear secondary resonance of FGPM micro/nano-beams subjected to an external hard periodic excitation is studied on the basis of the nonlocal strain gradient theory of elasticity. To attain this purpose, the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity within the framework of the Euler–Bernoulli beam theory and van Karman geometrical nonlinearity is applied. Thereafter, by employing proper mode shapes together with the Galerkin technique and using the multiple time scales method, explicit analytical expressions corresponding to the nonlocal strain gradient frequency–response and amplitude–response are obtained for both of the subharmonic and superharmonic ranges of the excitation frequency.

As mentioned previously, Lim, Zhang, and Reddy (2015) developed a more comprehensive size-dependent continuum theory of elasticity namely as the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory which has the capability to incorporate the both hardening-stiffness and softening–stiffness influences of small scale effects in a simultaneous form. Recently, several investigations have been carried out to extract the proper values of small-scale parameters using molecular dynamics simulations (Mehralian, Tadi Beni, and Karimi Zeverdejani 2017; Sahmani, Aghdam, and Bahrami 2017; Mohammadi, Rajabpour, and Ghadiri 2018; Madani, Sabour, and Fadaee 2018; Li, Lai, and Yang 2019). Also, some sensitivity and uncertainty analyses have been carried out for mechanical characteristics of nanostructures (Vu-Bac et al. 2016; Hamdia et al. 2017, 2018). sections.heading: 4. Numerical results and discussion
sections.text:
Herein, the nonlocal strain gradient nonlinear secondary resonance of FGPM silicon micro/nanobeams subjected to an external hard periodic excitation is shown corresponding to simply supported-simply supported (SS–SS), clamped–simply supported (C–SS) and clamped–clamped (C–C) boundary conditions. It is supposed that L=h ¼ 20; b ¼ h; and # ¼ 0:2:
Figures 2 and 3 illustrate the size-dependent frequency response of FGPM micro/nano-beams under subharmonic excitation corresponding to various values of the nonlocal parameter and strain gradient parameter, respectively. It is seen that the nonlocality causes to shift the junction point of the stable and unstable branches to the higher value of the detuning parameter. However, the strain gradient size dependency plays an opposite role. Moreover, it can be observed that by changing the boundary conditions from simply supported ones to clamped ones, the wide of the frequency–response (the gap between stable and unstable branches) reduces. It
Figure 11. Nonlocal strain gradient frequency–response of FGPM micro/nano-beams with different porosity dispersion patterns under superharmonic excitation (Cp ¼ 0:6; ~F ¼ 0:4; l ¼ l ¼ 25 nm).
means that for a simply supported FGPM micro/nano-beam, a wider range of frequency leads to a hard periodic excitation than a clamped one.
The size-dependent frequency–response of FGPM micro/nan-beams under superharmonic excitation is depicted in Figs. 4 and 5 corresponding to various values of the nonlocal parameter and strain gradient parameter, respectively. The jump phenomenon is obvious for this type of excitation and it is revealed that the nonlocal size effect makes an increment in the height of jump phenomenon and shifts the peak to higher value of the detuning parameter. However, the strain gradient small scale effect leads to decrease the height of the jump phenomenon and shifts the peak to lower value of the detuning parameter. It means that the nonlocality leads to decrease the stiffness of FGPM micro/nano-beam, but the strain gradient size effect causes to increase it. Furthermore, it is found that by changing the boundary conditions from simply supported ones to clamped ones, the nonlinearity reduces, so shifting the peak of jump phenomenon to higher value of the detuning parameter diminishes.
In Figs. 6 and 7, the size-dependent amplitude–response of FGPM micro/nano-beams under subharmonic excitation corresponding to different values of the nonlocal parameter and strain gradient parameter, respectively. It is shown that the nonlocal size dependency causes to increase the area occupied by the amplitude–response curve which involves higher value of the excitation

Also, it can be seen that these patterns are more significant by changing the boundary conditions from simply supported ones to clamped ones. It means that the small scale effects play more important role in the amplitude–response associated with the subharmonic excitation of a FGPM micro/nano-beam with clamped edge supports.
Figures 8 and 9 demonstrate the size-dependent amplitude–response of FGPM micro/nanobeams under superharmonic excitation corresponding to different values of the nonlocal parameter and strain gradient parameter, respectively. The jump up and jump down phenomena are obvious which results in two bifurcation points. It is found that the nonlocality makes an increment in the oscillation amplitude as well as the excitation amplitude associated with both of the bifurcation points. However, the strain gradient size dependency leads to decrease these values associated with the bifurcation points. In addition, it is revealed that for very high value of the excitation amplitude, the influence of nonlocal and strain gradient size effects diminishes.
The influence of the porosity dispersion pattern on the nonlocal strain gradient frequency–response of FGPM micro/nano-beams with different end supports is shown in Figs. 10 and 11 corresponding to the subharmonic and superharmonic excitations, respectively. In the subharmonic case, it is observed that the value of the detuning parameter at the junction point of the two

However, this difference between various patterns of the porosity dispersion becomes negligible by changing the boundary conditions from SS–SS ones to C–C ones. This pattern may be related to the enhancement in the stiffness of a FGPM micro/nano-beam with clamped end supports. In the superharmonic case, it is observed that the peak of the oscillation amplitude and the associated detuning parameter are maximum and minimum, respectively, for pattern D and pattern C of the porosity dispersion. This prediction is the same for all types of the end supports.
Figures 12 and 13 represent the influence of the porosity dispersion pattern on the nonlocal strain gradient amplitude–response of FGPM micro/nano-beams with different boundary conditions corresponding to the subharmonic and superharmonic excitations, respectively. In the subharmonic case, it can be seen that by changing the porosity dispersion pattern from pattern A to pattern D, from pattern D to pattern B, and from pattern B to pattern C, the specific range of the detuning parameter corresponding to which the FGPM micro/nano-beams is excited, shifts to a higher value. In the superharmonic case, it is found that the detuning parameter associated with the peak of the oscillation amplitude is maximum and minimum for FGPM micro/nanobeams with patterns C and A, respectively.

The influence of the porosity coefficient on the nonlocal strain gradient frequency–response of FGPM micro/nano-beams with uniform porosity dispersion (pattern A) and various end supports is shown in Figs. 14 and 15 corresponding to the subharmonic and superharmonic excitations, respectively. In the subharmonic case, it is revealed that by increasing the porosity coefficient, the value of the detuning parameter at the junction point of the two branches of the frequency–response curve reduces. This anticipation becomes more prominent by changing the boundary conditions from C–C ones to SS–SS ones. In the superharmonic case, it is indicated that an increment in the value of the porosity coefficient leads to decrease the peak of the oscillation amplitude and the associated value of the detuning parameter.
In Figs. 16 and 17, the influence of the porosity coefficient on the nonlocal strain gradient amplitude–response of FGPM micro/nano-beams with uniform porosity dispersion (pattern A) and various end supports is illustrated corresponding to the subharmonic and superharmonic excitations, respectively. In the subharmonic case, it is revealed that by increasing the value of the porosity coefficient, the specific range of the detuning parameter corresponding to which the FGPM micro/nano-beam is excited, shifts to higher value. In the superharmonic case, an increment in the value of the porosity coefficient results in to increase the detuning parameter associated with the peak of the oscillation amplitude. These observations are similar for all types of boundary conditions.

sections.heading: 5. Concluding remarks
sections.text:
The prime aim of this work was to predict the influence of the nonlocality and strain gradient size dependencies on the nonlinear secondary resonance of FGPM micro/nano-beams under hard periodic excitation including both of the subharmonic and superharmonic ones. To this end, the nonlocal strain gradient theory of elasticity was implemented to the classical Euler–Bernoulli beam theory to develop a unified size-dependent beam model. After that, the multiple time scales technique in conjunction with the Galerkin method was employed to extract the nonlocal strain gradient frequency–response and amplitude–response of the hard excited FGPM micro/ nano-beams.
It was found that for the subharmonic excitation, the nonlocality causes to shift the junction point of the stable and unstable branches to the higher value of the detuning parameter. However, the strain gradient size dependency plays an opposite role. By changing the boundary conditions from simply supported ones to clamped ones, the wide of the frequency–response (the gap between stable and unstable branches) reduces. Also, it was revealed that the nonlocal size dependency causes to increase the area occupied by the amplitude–response curve which involves higher value of the excitation amplitude. However, the strain gradient size effect has an opposite influence that leads to reduce the area occupied by the amplitude–response curve involved lower

However, the strain gradient small scale effect leads to decrease the height of the jump phenomenon and shifts the peak to lower value of the detuning parameter. Moreover, it was demonstrated that the nonlocality makes an increment in the oscillation amplitude as well as the excitation amplitude associated with both of the bifurcation points. However, the strain gradient size dependency leads to decrease these values associated with the bifurcation points.

referenceMentions.context: Zhang and Wang (2017) used thermal-bonding lamination technique to fabricate FGPMs including the both closed cell and open cell porosities.

Also, recently, an integral form of the nonlocal elasticity has been employed to analyze size-dependent mechanical characteristics of micro/nano-structures (Zhu and Li 2017a, 2017b; Mahmoudpour, Hosseini-Hashemi, and Faghidian 2018; Fakher, Rahmanian, and Hosseini-Hashemi 2019). In accordance with reviewing the historical background, it is common that size effect in type of the stress nonlocality demonstrates softening influence caused a reduction in the stiffness, while the strain gradient small scale effect plays a hardening role made an increment in the value of stiffness. It means that the previous proposed unconventional continuum theories have not the capability to cover the size dependencies in a perfect way. So, a new size-dependent elasticity theory namely nonlocal strain gradient theory was developed by Lim, Zhang, and Reddy (2015). After that, several investigation have been carried out using the new proposed non-classical continuum theory of elasticity.

As mentioned previously, Lim, Zhang, and Reddy (2015) developed a more comprehensive size-dependent continuum theory of elasticity namely as the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory which has the capability to incorporate the both hardening-stiffness and softening–stiffness influences of small scale effects in a simultaneous form.

metadata.abstractText: Functionally graded porous materials (FGPMs) have a wide range of applications as hollow members in biomedical and aeronautical engineering. In the FGPMs, the porosity is varied over the material volume because of the density change of pores. In the present work, an analytical treatment on the sizedependent nonlinear secondary resonance of FGPM micro/nano-beams subjected to periodic hard excitations is proposed in the simultaneous presence of the nonlocality and strain gradient size dependencies. Based upon the closed-cell Gaussian-random field scheme, the mechanical properties of the FGPM micro/nano-beams are extracted corresponding to the uniform and three different functionally graded patterns of the porosity dispersion. The nonlocal strain gradient theory of elasticity is applied to the classical beam theory to formulate a newly combined size-dependent beam model. Thereafter, an analytical solving methodology based on the multiple timescales together with the Galerkin technique is adopted to achieve the nonlocal strain gradient frequency–response and amplitude–response curves associated with the subharmonic and superharmonic external excitations. For the subharmonic excitation, it is observed that the nonlocality causes to shift the junction point of the stable and unstable branches to the higher value of the detuning parameter. However, the strain gradient size dependency plays an opposite role. For the superharmonic one, it is illustrated that the nonlocal size effect makes an increment in the height of jump phenomenon and shifts the peak to higher value of the detuning parameter. However, the strain gradient small scale effect leads to decrease the height of the jump phenomenon and shifts the peak to lower value of the detuning parameter. ARTICLE HISTORY Received 11 March 2019 Accepted 23 May 2019
